proud: Proud people focus on the failures of others.
broken: Broken people are overwhelmed with a sense of their own spiritual need.

proud: Proud people have a critical, fault-finding spirit; they look at everyone else’s faults with a microscope but their own with a telescope.
broken: Broken people are compassionate; they can forgive much because they know how much  they have been forgiven.

proud: Proud people are self-righteous; they look down on others.
broken: Broken people esteem all others better than themselves.

proud: Proud people have an independent, self-sufficient spirit.
broken: Broken people have a dependent spirit; they recognize their need for others.

proud: Proud people have to prove that they are right.
broken: Broken people are willing to yield the right to be right.

proud: Proud people claim rights; they have a demanding spirit.
broken: Broken people yield their rights; they have a meek spirit.

proud: Proud people are self-protective of their time, their rights, and their reputation.
broken: Broken people are self-denying.

proud: Proud people desire to be served.
broken: Broken people are motivated to serve others.

proud: Proud people desire to be a success.
broken: Broken people are motivated to be faithful and to make others a success.

proud: Proud people desire self-advancement.
broken: Broken people desire to promote others.

proud: Proud people have a drive to be recognized and appreciated.
broken: Broken people have a sense of their own unworthiness; they are thrilled that God would  use them at all.

proud: Proud people are wounded when others are promoted and they are overlooked.
broken: Broken people are eager for others to get the credit; they rejoice when others are lifted  up.

proud: Proud people have a subconscious feeling, “This ministry/church is privileged to have me and my gifts”; they think of what they can do for God.
broken: Broken people’s heart attitude is, “I don’t deserve to have a part in any ministry”; they  know that they have nothing to offer God except the life of Jesus flowing through their  broken lives.

proud: Proud people feel confident in how much they know.
broken: Broken people are humbled by how very much they have to learn.

proud: Proud people are self-conscious.
broken: Broken people are not concerned with self at all.

proud: Proud people keep others at arms’ length.
broken: Broken people are willing to risk getting close to others and to take risks of loving  intimately.

proud: Proud people are quick to blame others.
broken: Broken people accept personal responsibility and can see where they are wrong in a  situation.

proud: Proud people are unapproachable or defensive when criticized.
broken: Broken people receive criticism with a humble, open spirit.

proud: Proud people are concerned with being respectable, with what others think; they work to protect their own image and reputation.
broken: Broken people are concerned with being real; what matters to them is not what others  think but what God knows; they are willing to die to their own reputation.

proud: Proud people find it difficult to share their spiritual need with others.
broken: Broken people are willing to be open and transparent with others as God directs.

proud: Proud people want to be sure that no one finds out when they have sinned; their instinct is to cover up.
broken: Broken people, once broken, don’t care who knows or who finds out; they are willing to be  exposed because they have nothing to lose.

proud: Proud people have a hard time saying, “I was wrong; will you please forgive me?”
broken: Broken people are quick to admit failure and to seek forgiveness when necessary.

proud: Proud people tend to deal in generalities when confessing sin.
broken: Broken people are able to acknowledge specifics when confessing their sin.

proud: Proud people are concerned about the consequences of their sin.
broken: Broken people are grieved over the cause, the root of their sin.

proud: Proud people are remorseful over their sin, sorry that they got found out or caught.
broken: Broken people are truly, genuinely repentant over their sin, evidenced in the fact that they  forsake that sin.

proud: Proud people wait for the other to come and ask forgiveness when there is a misunderstanding or conflict in a relationship.
broken: Broken people take the initiative to be reconciled when there is misunderstanding or  conflict in relationships; they race to the cross; they see if they can get there first, no  matter how wrong the other may have been.

proud: Proud people compare themselves with others and feel worthy of honor.
broken: Broken people compare themselves to the holiness of God and feel a desperate need for  His mercy.

proud: Proud people are blind to their true heart condition.
broken: Broken people walk in the light.

proud: Proud people don’t think they have anything to repent of.
broken: Broken people realize they have need of a continual heart attitude of repentance.

proud: Proud people don’t think they need revival, but they are sure that everyone else does.
broken: Broken people continually sense their need for a fresh encounter with God and for a fresh  filling of His Holy Spirit.
